description: This course investigates the application of statics and dynamics to simple force analyses of the musculoskeletal system, introduces the fundamentals of the mechanics of materials, and introduces the biomechanics of soft and hard tissues (e.g, microstructure and mechanical properties). The first portion of the course will present fundamental concepts of force and mechanics of rigid and deformable bodies. The remainder of the course will consist of an introduction of materials science and engineering, including the classification and bulk properties of implantable materials.
name: INTRO TO BIOMECHANICS

values.comments:
BE200 is a course intended to delve deeper into the field of bioengineering, with the course split into a biomechanical based section and a biomaterials based section. There is one required text (W. F. Riley, L. D. Sturges, D. H. Morris, Mechanics of Materials, Fifth Edition, John Wiley and Sons, New York, 1999) with several optional suggested readings.

Students felt that the course curriculum was too broad, even for an introductory course, and felt that they got more of a cursory glance at biomechanics and biomaterials rather than a useful understanding.

Professor Nicoll’s lectures tended to drag on, and were not engaging, and lacked practical examples in favor of a theory-based presentation.
